Cross-lingual transfer is powerful (RQ1). Zero-shot learning reaches an F1 score of [REPLACE value="C:\Users\Alfy\Lavoro ristol	ransp-text-new
ode_modules\.bin luid" non � riconosciuto come comando interno o esterno,]% in the MEDIUM setup, which outperforms training the neural tagger on very limited gold data (plain). Neural NER is [REPLACE value="C:\Users\Alfy\Lavoro ristol	ransp-text-new
ode_modules\.bin luid" non � riconosciuto come comando interno o esterno,] than traditional HMM-based tagging (TnT) (Brants, 2000) and greatly improves by unsupervised word embedding initialization (+Poly). It is noteworthy that zero-shot transfer benefits only to a limiting degree from more source data (F1 increases by almost [REPLACE value="C:\Users\Alfy\Lavoro ristol	ransp-text-new
ode_modules\.bin luid" non � riconosciuto come comando interno o esterno,]% when training on all English CoNLL data). To compare cross-lingual transfer to limited gold data (RQ2), we observe that training the neural system on the small amount of data together with Polyglot embeddings is close to the tiny-shot transfer setup. Few-shot learning greatly improves over zero-shot learning. The [REPLACE value="C:\Users\Alfy\Lavoro ristol	ransp-text-new
ode_modules\.bin luid" non � riconosciuto come comando interno o esterno,] way is to add the target data to the source, in comparison to fine-tuning. In both MEDIUM and LARGE setups are further gains obtained by adding TINY or SMALL amounts of Danish gold data. Interestingly, a) finetuning is less effective; b) it is

from a medium-sized setup than from the entire CoNLL source data.

Note: The phrase "C:\Users\Alfy\Lavoro\bristol\transp-text-new\node_modules\.bin\fluid" non � riconosciuto come comando interno o esterno," appears to be an error message rather than a value that should be replaced. Please verify the intended values for replacement in this text.
